Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 9: The Bodhisattva's Education

A few years after that the Bodhisattva, together with five hundred children of the same age, was sent off to the school of a learned man who was sometimes called Sarvamitra (Kun gyi bshes gnyen) and at other times *Khajuvarman (Srin bu'i go cha).
Manual - English: As he grows up slightly, to a minimal extent, he learns letters with a teacher of letters, math with a math teacher, horse and elephant riding skills with Maternal Uncle, Mātulasulabha (bzang len), Archery and so forth with a teacher of weapons.

Sun of Faith - English: Each time the instructor would inscribe an alphabet to teach it to the prince,
Siddhartha would speak out: “I know it already, I would like to learn another.”
Sarvamitra produced five hundred different scripts for the Bodhisattva but got no response except the one above.
“I have presented to you all the scripts found in the world,” the master admitted at last. “To my knowledge there exist no others.”
Upon this, the Bodhisattva wrote out an alphabet and showed it to Sarvamitra
—who conceded that he had never seen such lettering.
“That sort of script spreads throughout the world,” the child asserted, when a universal monarch or bodhisattva is born to it.”
At that very instant, the god Maha-brahma (Tshangs pa chen po) thundered from on high: “That's perfectly true!”
The child was then sent off to learn mathematics under the strict tutelage of Master Arjuna (Srid sgrub).
Scene working notes: I could not find the Bodhisattva's study with the Mathematician, Arjuna (srid sgrub) in any Vinaya texts. The episode, however, appears in detail in the Latitavistara-sūtra (sde dge bka' 'gyur, vol. 46, 75b.2

Sun of Faith - English: But the Bodhisattva, since he was already proficient in all the known mathematical theorems,
started to reel off an interminable series of numbers and astrological calculations of which the tutor had never even heard.
Subsequently Siddhartha learned to ride and control elephants from his maternal uncle *Sulabha (Bzang len).
The expert archer Sahadeva (Lhar bcas) taught him the five ways of throwing weapons designed for hurling
Whereas the Bodhisattva excelled in all the arts and skills even before training could get underway,
the other Shakya children had to learn and practise in the normal way.
As regards to the five ways of throwing weapons, they are: throwing from a great distance,
throwing solely guided by the sound [of the target],
throwing to kill,
throwing stealthily so as to catch by surprise,
and throwing at great speed [in an emergency].
Aware of the hate that Devadatta (Lhas byin) harbored for his princely cousin,
the weapons instructor refused to teach the former how to throw so as to kill.
